pullRequest.body:
Contains the definition of the graph laplacian and proofs of some its properties, including that it is positive semidefinite and that the dimension of its nullspace equals the number of connected components of the graph.

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

nodes.body: I merged master into this branch in order to use ```PosSemidef.toLinearMapâ‚‚'_zero_iff``` from #8809. Was this a mistake? This branch is now 500 commits ahead which is not what I intended. How do I fix this?

The usual recipe is to make a new fresh branch from master, and then import your old changes into it using `git merge --squash`, which destroys the git history. Then you "force push" the new branch to GitHub (`git push --force`). Some open source projects are very insistent that destroying git history is a bad thing, but mathlib has its own way of doing things (and each PR gets squashed down to a single commit, with a new label, when it gets merged anyway).

I think it's best if I fix this, since I have a clean copy of your old git branch saved. Here you go.

When you want to work further on this, I suggest killing your current git branch and then checking out the new branch from GitHub:
```
git fetch
git branch -D awueth-lapMatrix
git checkout origin/awueth-lapMatrix
```

> When you want to work further on this, I suggest killing your current git branch and then checking out the new branch from GitHub:
> 
> ```
> git fetch
> git branch -D awueth-lapMatrix
> git checkout origin/awueth-lapMatrix
> ```

Thanks a lot! It looks to be working nicely again.
Merge conflict now fixed, please review!
LGTM
It wasn't merging cleanly so I have force-pushed a new, rebased branch.

:v: awueth can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
`bors merge`

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8080576564/job/22077335507)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8080576564/job/22077334749)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8080576564/job/22077334477)

The remaining `unfold`'s aren't so much a sign of missing API, as of existing API which hasn't been used (fortunately, since most of them are unfolding pre-existing mathlib definitions, rather than ones added in this PR). I'm posting suggested reformulations which avoid the unfoldings entirely.

Thanks for all the work on this!

There are just two mathlib naming convention issues I noticed, and once you fix those, let's merge.

bors d+

I have now delegated merging rights to you. After you address the comments, you can create a comment that contains `bors merge` on a line of its own, and that will send it off into the next merge batch. It is usually courteous to wait until the CI passes on your own branch before sending it to bors, since the batch fails if any included PR fails.

I've added some suggestions. Most of this is just minor "golfing" of proofs (expressing the same argument in slightly fewer lines). The only major point is that it would be nicer to work with the kernel of the Laplacian as an endomorphism of the space of functions on V, rather than what you do here, which is actually to regard it as a map from that space to its own dual.
Some comments, mostly naming and style.

I pushed some cosmetic changes, and wrapped everything in the `SimpleGraph` namespace.

There's some missing API still. I added a couple theorems. Basically, much of the time when there's an `unfold`, it indicates that there's some lemma that's missing. I suspect `lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚'` for example contains some intermediate results that we'd want.

We don't need to go too deep into this before we merge, but I want to be sure that we have lemmas like the ones in AdjMatrix surrounding the definitions so that we don't need to `unfold` so much.

(I left one comment; I haven't done a very careful review for other such lemmas yet.)

The remaining `unfold`'s aren't so much a sign of missing API, as of existing API which hasn't been used (fortunately, since most of them are unfolding pre-existing mathlib definitions, rather than ones added in this PR). I'm posting suggested reformulations which avoid the unfoldings entirely.

Thanks for all the work on this!

There are just two mathlib naming convention issues I noticed, and once you fix those, let's merge.

bors d+

I have now delegated merging rights to you. After you address the comments, you can create a comment that contains `bors merge` on a line of its own, and that will send it off into the next merge batch. It is usually courteous to wait until the CI passes on your own branch before sending it to bors, since the batch fails if any included PR fails.
Does tagging this as simp benefit you anywhere? I can't think of how it would but I may be missing something!

No, I just saw that the equivalent theorem for the adjacency matrix was tagged with simp and assumed it was good practice. Should I remove @[simp] where it is not needed? I might not use them anywhere since I mostly used simp only [...].

Hmm indeed that sounds strange to me. Well you should think about how likely it is that the lemma will be used by simp, generally lemmas that are an equality or iff statement where the LHS is more complicated than the RHS are the obvious ones. If the statement is some property like this then it is generally rarer that simp would be the tactic people would be using on goals containing that property, they'd just use that single lemma directly
I'm not sure if `[Ring R]` is the best assumption here, generally we go as weak as possible, so I'd it least try and include the naturals, but this should make sense for any `AddMonoidWithOne` I hope

Probably you should put the R and the assumptions as a line `variable` at the start of a section of you have to repeat it a lot. I would also think R should be implicit for a lot of these, as R can be read off from the type of the thing being proved and there is likely only one possible R under consideration in any proof about these things
I suspect many of the import lines are redundant, since "import" is transitive (and I suspect virtually every file in the library imports Fintype.Card etc).
This is a non-terminal `simp` (doesn't close the goal) - best avoided in library code since it can break in unpredictable ways if the simp lemma set changes
In this proof there are multiple goals being opened + closed without indentation to show this. I think a documentation string for this lemma would be good as well
Probably "spd" is a typo (but I think it should be expanded, see above)
Maybe better to put this in the "PosSemidef" namespace (i.e. name it as "PosSemidef.spectral_theorem")

Indenting is off slightly here. More importantly, it is bad for readability that we wait so long before killing the easy goal with "exact two_pos" â€“ you can use "refine" or "swap" to quickly deal with easy side-goals before going on with the main proof.
It seems a little clumsy to have a long proof inside the `def` of a function â€“Â can you factor out the proof argument into an auxiliary lemma?
non-terminal `simp` again

```suggestion
  Â· exact fun h i j hA â†¦ h i j (Adj.reachable hA)
```

```suggestion
    Â· exact (h i j hA).trans h'
```
You now have two variables called `i` at once

This theorem and the one below should be in a much earlier file. Maybe in Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.Defs next to [ite_add](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Defs.html#ite_add)
No actually, `P` does not need multiplication! This should work with just `AddGroup`. Maybe move these to Mathlib.Algebra.Group.Basic ?

I renamed both theorems and made them more general, I hope this is better:
```lean
theorem ite_sub_ite {Î± : Type*} [Sub Î±] (P : Prop) [Decidable P] (a b c d : Î±) :
    ((if P then a else b) - if P then c else d) = if P then a - c else b - d := by
  split
  repeat rfl

theorem ite_add_ite {Î± : Type*} [Add Î±] (P : Prop) [Decidable P] (a b c d : Î±) :
    ((if P then a else b) + if P then c else d) = if P then a + c else b + d := by
  split
  repeat rfl
```
I'm not quite sure where to put it in `AddGroup`. Also `ite_add` does not need multiplication either, why is it in Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.Defs? Finally if I put these two theorems in another file, should I create a new pull request?

Good point. Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.Defs sounds good then. 

No, you don't need a new PR. It's ok to have multiple files being edited in a single PR.
This PR is really cool btw. I'm looking forward to it getting merged and having more Spectral Graph Theory in mathlib.
I tried to move the theorems but I get an error when trying to rebuild the imports.
Got it done now

You can fold these two lemmas together:
```suggestion
theorem isSymm_lapMatrix [AddGroupWithOne Î±] : (G.lapMatrix Î±).IsSymm := by
  rw [Matrix.IsSymm, lapMatrix, degMatrix, transpose_sub, diagonal_transpose, transpose_adjMatrix]
```

golf:
```suggestion
theorem lapMatrix_mulVec_const_eq_zero [Ring Î±] : mulVec (G.lapMatrix Î±) (fun _ â†¦ 1) = 0 := by
  ext1 i
  simp_rw [lapMatrix, sub_mulVec, Pi.sub_apply, adjMatrix_mulVec_apply, degMatrix, mulVec,
    dotProduct, diagonal]
  simp
```

```suggestion
  unfold mulVec dotProduct
  simp [mul_sum]
```

```suggestion
theorem sum_adj_eq_degree [AddCommMonoidWithOne Î±] (i : V) :
    (G.degree i : Î±) = âˆ‘ j : V, if G.Adj i j then 1 else 0 := by
  unfold degree neighborFinset neighborSet
  rw [sum_boole, Set.toFinset_setOf]
```

```suggestion
theorem lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚' [LinearOrderedField Î±] (x : V â†’ Î±) :
    toLinearMapâ‚‚' (G.lapMatrix Î±) x x = (âˆ‘ i, âˆ‘ j, if G.Adj i j then (x i - x j)^2 else 0) / 2 := by
  simp_rw [toLinearMapâ‚‚'_apply', lapMatrix, sub_mulVec, dotProduct_sub, dotProduct_mulVec_degMatrix,
    dotProduct_mulVec_adjMatrix, â† sum_sub_distrib, sum_adj_eq_degree, sum_mul, â† sum_sub_distrib,
    ite_mul, one_mul, zero_mul, ite_sub_ite, sub_zero]
  rw [â† half_add_self (âˆ‘ x_1 : V, âˆ‘ x_2 : V, _)]
  conv_lhs => arg 1; arg 2; arg 2; intro i; arg 2; intro j; rw [if_congr (adj_comm G i j)]
  conv_lhs => arg 1; arg 2; rw [Finset.sum_comm]
  simp_rw [â† sum_add_distrib, ite_add_ite]
  congr 2 with i
  congr 2 with j
  ring_nf
```

```suggestion
theorem isPosSemidef_lapMatrix [LinearOrderedField Î±] [StarOrderedRing Î±] [TrivialStar Î±] :
    PosSemidef (G.lapMatrix Î±) := by
  constructor
  Â· rw [IsHermitian, conjTranspose_eq_transpose_of_trivial, isSymm_lapMatrix]
  Â· intro x
    rw [star_trivial, â† toLinearMapâ‚‚'_apply', lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚']
    refine div_nonneg (sum_nonneg' fun i â†¦ sum_nonneg' fun j â†¦ ?_) two_pos.le
    split
    Â· apply sq_nonneg
    Â· rfl
```

This can be golfed a lot:
```suggestion
theorem lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚'_apply'_zero_iff_adj [LinearOrderedField Î±] (x : V â†’ Î±) :
    Matrix.toLinearMapâ‚‚' (G.lapMatrix Î±) x x = 0 â†” âˆ€ i j : V, G.Adj i j â†’ x i = x j := by
  constructor
  Â· intro h i j
    by_contra hn
    push_neg at hn
    suffices hc : toLinearMapâ‚‚' (G.lapMatrix Î±) x x > 0
    Â· exact gt_irrefl _ (h â–¸ hc)
    rw [lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚']
    refine div_pos (sum_pos' (Î» k _ â†¦ sum_nonneg' (Î» l â†¦ ?_)) ?_) two_pos
    Â· split_ifs
      Â· apply sq_nonneg
      Â· rfl
    Â· refine âŸ¨i, mem_univ _, sum_pos' (Î» k _ â†¦ ?_) âŸ¨j, mem_univ _, ?_âŸ©âŸ©
      Â· split_ifs
        Â· apply sq_nonneg
        Â· rfl
      Â· simpa only [hn, ite_true, gt_iff_lt, sub_pos] using
          sq_pos_of_ne_zero _ (sub_ne_zero.mpr hn.2)
  Â· intro h
    rw [lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚', div_eq_zero_iff]
    refine Or.inl <| sum_eq_zero Î» i _ â†¦ (sum_eq_zero Î» j _ â†¦ ?_)
    simpa only [ite_eq_right_iff, zero_lt_two, pow_eq_zero_iff, sub_eq_zero] using h i j
```

I think it would be cleaner to express this in terms of `Matrix.toLin'` (i.e. interpreting A as a linear, not bilinear, map). Can you show
```
theorem PosSemidef.toLin'_zero_iff (A : Matrix V V â„) (h_psd : PosSemidef A) (x : V â†’ â„) :
    Matrix.toLinearMapâ‚‚' A x x = 0 â†” Matrix.toLin' A x = 0 := by sorry
```
? Then you can replace most of the uses of `toLinearMapâ‚‚'` (the ones which aren't explicitly using the bilinear form) further down the file with `toLin'`.
I proved it but I guess this theorem wont be needed anymore once `PosSemidef.dotProduct_mulVec_zero_iff` from PR https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8809 is available

```suggestion
  Â· rw [â† ConnectedComponent.eq] at h
    exact (hâ‚‚ (hâ‚ â–¸ h.symm)).elim
  Â· rw [â† ConnectedComponent.eq] at h
    exact (hâ‚ (hâ‚ƒ â–¸ h)).elim
```

All the lemmas about positive-semidef matrices will have to be moved into `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Matrix.PosDef` or somewhere similar. It might be nice to add, at the same time, the following characterisation of positive semidefinite matrices:
```
lemma Matrix.posSemidef_iff_exists_eq_transpose_mul_self {A : Matrix V V â„} : 
    PosSemidef A â†” âˆƒ (B : Matrix V V â„), A = Báµ€ * B := 
  âŸ¨fun hA â†¦ âŸ¨_, hA.spectral_theoremâŸ©, fun âŸ¨B, hBâŸ© â†¦ (hB â–¸ posSemidef_conjTranspose_mul_self B)âŸ©
```
I've made a separate PR #8809 for the linear-algebra parts (crediting you as a contributor) â€“ I hope that's OK with you.
Thats fine with me, thanks!

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [â† half_add_self (âˆ‘ x_1 : V, âˆ‘ x_2 : V, _)] ```

```suggestion
* `SimpleGraph.lapMatrix`: The Laplacian matrix of a simple graph, defined as the difference
```

```suggestion
and `A` the adjacency matrix of `G`. -/
```

```suggestion
$$x^{\top} L x = \sum_{i \sim j} (x_{i}-x_{j})^{2}$$
where $\sim$ denotes the adjacency relation -/
```
Given the theorem statement, it would be in the reverse order. Maybe throw in an `if`? So `degree_eq_sum_if_adj`
The name should have `eq` in there. Maybe `forall` too? `lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚'_apply'_eq_zero_iff_forall_adj`

```suggestion
theorem lapMatrix_toLin'_apply_eq_zero_iff_forall_adj (x : V â†’ â„) :
```

```suggestion
theorem lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚'_apply'_eq_zero_iff_forall_reachable (x : V â†’ â„) :
```

```suggestion
theorem lapMatrix_toLin'_apply_eq_zero_iff_forall_reachable (x : V â†’ â„) : Matrix.toLin' (G.lapMatrix â„) x = 0 â†”
```

I'm not sure what to call this. Here's an option.
```suggestion
lemma mem_ker_toLin'_lapMatrix_of_connectedComponent {G : SimpleGraph V} [DecidableRel G.Adj]
```

```suggestion
`V â†’ â„` which is `1` on the vertices in `c` and `0` elsewhere.
The family of these maps indexed by the connected components of `G` proves to be a basis
of the kernel of `lapMatrix G R` -/
```

I think this should go the other way?
```suggestion
lemma linearIndependent_lapMatrix_ker_basis_aux :
```

Mathlib names always follow the syntax of the lemma, not the meaning of it, unless "spanning" is a convention specified somewhere and I'm not familiar with it.
```suggestion
lemma top_le_span_range_lapMatrix_ker_basis_aux :
```

```suggestion
the basis is made up of the functions `V â†’ â„` which are `1` on the vertices of the given
connected component and `0` elsewhere. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- The number of connected components in `G` is the dimension of the nullspace its Laplacian. -/
```
This should go into the AdjMatrix module
Done. I'm not sure about in the placement though, i feel like it could also go below `adjMatrix_vecMul_apply`.

```suggestion
  simp only [dotProduct, mulVec, adjMatrix_apply, ite_mul, one_mul, zero_mul, mul_sum, mul_ite,
    mul_zero]
```
Are `unfold`'s something that should be avoided in general?
In the cases below I see why it makes sense but here using 'unfold' appears more readable to me.

```suggestion
  simp only [dotProduct, degMatrix, mulVec_diagonal, â† mul_assoc, mul_comm]
```

```suggestion
  simp_rw [degree, neighborFinset, neighborSet, sum_boole]
  rw [Set.toFinset_setOf]
```
(for some reason `simp_rw` won't fire on `Set.toFinset_setOf` -- maybe it doesn't locate the decidability instances?)

```suggestion
  simp_rw [toLinearMapâ‚‚'_apply', lapMatrix, sub_mulVec, dotProduct_sub, dotProduct_mulVec_degMatrix,
    dotProduct_mulVec_adjMatrix, â† sum_sub_distrib, degree_eq_sum_if_adj, sum_mul, ite_mul, one_mul,
    zero_mul, â† sum_sub_distrib, ite_sub_ite, sub_zero]
```

```suggestion
  refine âŸ¨?_, fun h i j hA â†¦ h i j hA.reachableâŸ©
  Â· intro h i j âŸ¨wâŸ©
    induction' w with w i j _ hA _ h'
    Â· rfl
    Â· exact (h i j hA).trans h'
```

```suggestion
    by_contra! hn
    suffices hc : toLinearMapâ‚‚' (G.lapMatrix Î±) x x > 0
    Â· exact gt_irrefl _ (h â–¸ hc)
    rw [lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚']
    refine div_pos (sum_pos' (fun k _ â†¦ sum_nonneg' (fun l â†¦ ?_)) ?_) two_pos
    Â· exact ite_nonneg (sq_nonneg _) le_rfl
    Â· refine âŸ¨i, mem_univ _, sum_pos' (fun k _ â†¦ ?_) âŸ¨j, mem_univ _, ?_âŸ©âŸ©
      Â· exact ite_nonneg (sq_nonneg _) le_rfl
      Â· simpa only [hn, ite_true, gt_iff_lt, sub_pos] using
          sq_pos_of_ne_zero _ (sub_ne_zero.mpr hn.2)
  Â· intro h
    rw [lapMatrix_toLinearMapâ‚‚', div_eq_zero_iff]
    refine Or.inl <| sum_eq_zero fun i _ â†¦ (sum_eq_zero fun j _ â†¦ ?_)
```
(I think `Î»` is deprecated in favour of `fun` in mathlib 4.)

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Laplacian matrix of a simple graph

nodes.body: I've added some suggestions. Most of this is just minor "golfing" of proofs (expressing the same argument in slightly fewer lines). The only major point is that it would be nicer to work with the kernel of the Laplacian as an endomorphism of the space of functions on V, rather than what you do here, which is actually to regard it as a map from that space to its own dual.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(LinearAlgebra/Matrix/PosDef): unique positive semidef square root

nodes.body: I merged master into this branch in order to use ```PosSemidef.toLinearMapâ‚‚'_zero_iff``` from #8809. Was this a mistake? This branch is now 500 commits ahead which is not what I intended. How do I fix this?

The usual recipe is to make a new fresh branch from master, and then import your old changes into it using `git merge --squash`, which destroys the git history. Then you "force push" the new branch to GitHub (`git push --force`). Some open source projects are very insistent that destroying git history is a bad thing, but mathlib has its own way of doing things (and each PR gets squashed down to a single commit, with a new label, when it gets merged anyway).

I think it's best if I fix this, since I have a clean copy of your old git branch saved. Here you go.

When you want to work further on this, I suggest killing your current git branch and then checking out the new branch from GitHub:
```
git fetch
git branch -D awueth-lapMatrix
git checkout origin/awueth-lapMatrix
```

> When you want to work further on this, I suggest killing your current git branch and then checking out the new branch from GitHub:
> 
> ```
> git fetch
> git branch -D awueth-lapMatrix
> git checkout origin/awueth-lapMatrix
> ```

Thanks a lot! It looks to be working nicely again.

We don't need to go too deep into this before we merge, but I want to be sure that we have lemmas like the ones in AdjMatrix surrounding the definitions so that we don't need to `unfold` so much.

(I left one comment; I haven't done a very careful review for other such lemmas yet.)

The remaining `unfold`'s aren't so much a sign of missing API, as of existing API which hasn't been used (fortunately, since most of them are unfolding pre-existing mathlib definitions, rather than ones added in this PR). I'm posting suggested reformulations which avoid the unfoldings entirely.
